head.title: Tools Offer Glimpse of Long-Ago Science

hedline.hl1: Tools Offer Glimpse of Long-Ago Science

abstract.p: Comment on centuries-old scientific instruments that are being auctioned off by Christie's; photos (M)

block.p: Nowadays, researchers take for granted a huge array of precision instruments and machines that would have dazzled their predecessors in science and engineering.
But though their powers may be primitive, many devices used decades or even centuries ago were devised with such ingenuity that they dazzle today in their own way.

But though their powers may be primitive, many devices used decades or even centuries ago were devised with such ingenuity that they dazzle today in their own way.
These scientific, engineering and medical instruments, to be auctioned tonight by Christie's, Beverly Hills, are examples.
The instrument above, a cosmo-sphere made in the United States in the mid-19th century, shows the positions of the continents relative to longitude and the signs of the Zodiac.
At right is a 19th-century tellurian, an instrument in which spheres representing the Earth and the Moon move around the Sun.
As the detail shows, the instrument was made in London.
A calculating machine, far right, top, works as its ivory-handled gear is turned.
The instrument at far right, bottom, is a rare binocular microscope, dating from the mid-19th century.
